Replying to @sankalped 2018-10-09 11:17
@sankalped @Netlify It doesn't. There is no webserver to perform server-side rendering at request-time. Instead think of @Netlify as a CDN to serve your pre-rendered sites. Includes are typically performed by the templating of a SSG at build time. See https://t.co/8e7Iwrxmwj for leading SSGs
  • Permalink

Replying to @lunelson 2018-10-09 09:58
@lunelson @Netlify Changing anything at all in your package.json would have the same effect as having a flag in your commits which indicated that you should get all the dependencies again. Bumping the version number or updating a date. Anything. Your could continue to point your deps at branches.

Replying to @brob 2018-10-02 06:25
@brob @Netlify I don't think that's possible. The endpoint for a form is generated for you automatically by the build bots when they 'see' a form in your html at deploy time. I stub out all the forms I'll need on one page that I never link to if I want endpoints but no visible forms.

Replying to @GatsbyJS 2018-09-26 20:53
@gatsbyjs @presentday @Netlify Cache management is tricky so we simplify it for you by not exposing cache controls between the immutable, atomic builds. but... there is a way to manually cache things between builds on @Netlify. Just be careful! @stefanjudis of @contentful blogged it: https://t.co/ozAnzcc2VF

Replying to @smakosh 2018-09-25 12:30
@smakosh @Netlify @gatsbyjs Aha. When you submit the form data, you've omitted the recaptcha value. So your form submission would be viewed as spam and ignored. https://t.co/sARIpW2Mlp The reference examples submits everything, including the global recapture value. See here: https://t.co/ZzRyshZ7aR
  • Permalink

Replying to @smakosh 2018-09-25 11:54
@smakosh @Netlify It looks like you're using @gatsbyjs for your site, and that it doesn't expose a form as HTML (which the Netlify build bots need in order to create a form API for you) There is some good info on this in the docs: https://t.co/r9JA6RO6wR and an example: https://t.co/51koEBvVHl
